answers: The primary tumor slide from the thyroid gland shows large B-cell lymphoma, diffuse and follicular, WHO grade 3A. The histology reveals a confluent, nodular-to-diffuse, patternless infiltrate of lymphomatous medium-to-large cells with open nuclei, granular chromatin, spotty karyorrhexis, relatively inconspicuous nucleoli, and ample cytoplasm. The lymphoma is based on CD21-immunoreactive follicular dendritic meshworks, which maintain circumscription in nodular areas but are extensively expanded and disrupted in diffuse areas. The tumor cells are diffusely positive for CD20 and coexpress CD10. The Ki-67 proliferation fraction is high at 26%, indicating moderate anisokaryosis among the medium-to-large cells. There is an intermingled, diminutive centrocytic component, and the lymphoma is negative for bcl-2 and MUM.1. The slide also shows atrophic thyroid follicles amidst a background of lymphocytic thyroiditis.
